 # Important to note - if anything needs to be updated or changed, it should be done soon

The East Colo is located in Sterling 9, Building 1A, DH202 9MW, on the second floor.

Address:

{{Cyrus One}}

{{Attn: Mark Ellis}}

{{Sterling 9 – Building 1A}}

{{43290 Old Ox Road}}

{{Sterling, VA 20166}}

The space contains four pods (A-D), each pod has 20 racks.

On 12/20/2021, the CyrusOne, GSS and Kyndryl team met to discuss the facility and conduct a virtual walk-through.  The intent of the meeting was to provide the GSS team an initial view in the facility, ask questions and prepare for the future camera security surveillance site-survey.  Meeting Notes:
 #  *General:* CyrusOne data center team on the call to present diagrams and depictions of new greenfield data center space located in Sterling, VA.  We want to review with Ed, GSS, to ensure he and RTX GSS team understand plans, give Ed a chance to ask questions, and talk about expectation around GSS future camera installation work.
 #  *Sterling, VA* \{*}Site{*}{*}:{*} Dave Ragone from CyrusOne shared "CyrusOne Sterling 9 - Master Site Plan.pdf".  He explained that new greenfield space is located in new 1A Building, 2nd floor, Data Hall 202.
 #  *Sterling, VA* {*}Floor Plan{*}{*}:{*} Dave next shared "Sterling 9 Building floor plan.pdf".  Showed us 3 areas coded in blue.  1st is the actual raised floor space, roughly 2700 SF close to the middle of Data Hall 202.  Space is rectangular in shape.  2nd is the secure storage area also coded in blue, 3rd is an office for the onsite Kyndryl data center focal.
 #  *Sterling, VA* {*}Rack Layout{*}{*}:{*} Dave next shared "Kyndryl 80 Cabs Sterling 9 DH202 112221 Power.pdf'.  Raised floor space is 26' wide, 104' long.  Diagram show 80 total racks grouped in pods of 20.  Cold isle goes down the middle.  There are 2 swing doors at either end.  Caging is mesh except for right hand side which is solid.

Ed asked about cold air source, cold air comes up from under the floor through perforated tiles.  Asked about caging and whether anyone could gain access from under the tiles.  CyrusOne team explained security mesh is also under tiles, prohibits any access from underneath.

Ed asked about the yellow coded cabinets, CyrusOne explained that these are the RPPs (Remote Power Panels), power feeds for the space.  RPPs are about 6' in height, would not expect these to block any camera views unless cameras placed directly behind them.

Additional discussion points:
 * There would be a cage topper on each pod.
 * Cameras need to be directed inward, cannot view common space or any other tenant's space.
 * Cage doors would have biometric readers.  Storage area has badge reader for access.
 * Raised floor tiles are removable, not bolted to floor.
 * Cameras would need to be installed in cage and also in storage area.  Cameras would need a power source and connect to RTX LAN network.  Inside cage, could use existing PDU and LAN network.  Inside storage area would need to request power and cabling back to cage, it's roughly few hundred feet from storage area to cage.

 #  *Plans, Expectations, & Next Steps:* Team discussed expectations and rough plans.  Ed has enough to get a rough idea of the space and layout.  He would engage Convergint to do an actual on site walk through once space and caging are in place, per current plans would be late Jan to early Feb 2022.  Convergint would walk through, generate quote, then RTX would agree, fund, and line up the work.  Ed estimates could be 6 to 8 weeks to obtain equipment/cameras.  Michael brought up that build plans are working from an accelerated schedule, there's a possibility that equipment could get delivered on site and we need to move it into the cage before cameras are fully operational.  Ed said that he and GSS team can work with us if that's the case, that although it's ideal to have cameras installed and operational before any equipment is moved into the cage, understands potential need to move equipment in before cameras are ready.

If questions come up, Ed will reach out via e-mail.  Once we get closer to having the new greenfield space ready, Michael will schedule another call to schedule an onsite walk through.;;;

15/Dec/21 4:36 PM;andy.chan@rtx.com;Closing this item based on information from Michele:

Based on this morning’s call we are officially closing out this portion of the network segmentation workstream.  There is a lot of interest in continuing this as a project outside of Optimus and I will work that through with Dan and Tyler and circle back with our stakeholder team to update them accordingly on what to expect.  I may not get that communication out until January depending on what those next steps are but will plan to do that so that everyone understands where this is landing.
--------------------------------------------

With this discussion I will be formally closing out the work effort in the Network Transformation project.  Based on Tyler and Marty’s input, we are aligned that there is value to continuing to pursue this effort outside of the Optimus program however there are limited resources and funding at this time.

 

The recommended approach is to get this on the Cyber PMO radar for a 2022 work effort as a LAN and User Segmentation project.  This would allow us to further scope the capabilities, understand the current state of the environment and evaluate funding needs.  Also look at opportunities to enable capabilities in the new RTX remote access environment and potentially pilot the capability in Corp offices if the LAN supports 802.1x.  Ultimately we’ll want to gather the information needed to develop a roadmap for the next several years that will allow us to prepare and work this through the necessary funding and resource processes. 

 

I do want to circle back with all the stakeholders that were involved in helping develop this recommendation and set some expectations for the next steps so I’ll continue to work with Dan and Tyler to define that path forward.

---------------------------------------------

 

As part of the Optimus Network Transformation project under Marty Tice we’ve had a sub team working on network segmentation – how to ensure we maintain the existing compliance boundaries as we move into the new network, collapse/consolidate segmentation points in to the new performance hubs and has the flexibility to support organizational changes as well as compliance changes in the future. 

 

As a part of this sub team we’ve also been evaluating the capability Collins has been deploying using Cisco ISE for posture assessments integrated with the hub firewalls to provide additional controls for the cross boundary access within Collins. We’ve been engaging with key Cyber leads at RTX Corporate along with Pratt, Collins, RMD and RIS to review this capability and discuss how this can be leveraged in the future for RTX.  While there is great interest in pursuing this, continued effort on this is not in scope or budget for the Network Transformation project.

This meeting will be to review our recommendation to create a 2022 project for this, sponsored by RTX Enterprise Cybersecurity and Corporate Cybersecurity, in partnership with the Collins team and RTX EIS. ;;;

column234:
23/Jun/21 9:54 AM;max.chang@rtx.com;This risk was raised by Infra Ops Design and lead Linda Kent/John Murphy as long-tail circuits and the WAN inventory needs to be managed out of a central location to facilitate ongoing WAN turn-up for 65 back-to-office sites. In general, Network WAN Circuit orders must go out at least 2 months prior to inventory staging and installation / on-site turn-up and visits scheduled with limited access to sites due to COVID.

First step is to work with the TEM team to facilitate an PO, WAN Circuit to Cross-Connect service mapping, and ordering process for long-cycle procurement which requires dates from the originating PO documentation. Then, site augmentations can be planned / prioritized based on the sizing and expected delivery dates for various WAN circuits. Those devices that require a fabricated microchip with known constraints (a legacy fabrication / lithography process) can be prioritized last if need be. Those devices and vendors that do not rely on a legacy fab will go first.;;;
